name: Kepler-140
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-140 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-140 is a star with 1.67 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.29 times its radius. It is located 1936.71 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-140 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-140 b

Kepler-140 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.25 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-140.

The mass of Kepler-140 b is 3.04 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-140 b is 1.61 that of Earth. At 3.04 Earth masses, Kepler-140 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-140 c

Kepler-140 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.41 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 91.35 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-140.

The mass of Kepler-140 c is 3.97 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-140 c is 1.8 that of Earth. At 3.97 Earth masses, Kepler-140 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-140, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
